Headline.Para: One With a Lot of Tweets

LeadPara.Para: THURSDAY PUZZLE -- As the person in charge of the social media for Wordplay (you can twut at Wordplay on Twitter or follow me on Facebook), I got a vicarious thrill out of today's puzzle by Ross Trudeau.
People on social media are under a lot of pressure to rack up some of the things Mr. Trudeau mentions in his theme clues, and to see them written out as puns really helps let off a lot of steam.

TailParas.Para: So thank you for that, Mr. Trudeau. That's one fewer therapy session for me.
Today's Theme

If you are as neck-deep in social media as I am, you are aware of the plethora of ways you can engage with other people online, such as ''liking'' something they've ''posted,'' or ''tweeting'' what they've ''shared.'' It's exhausting and it goes on forever, but it is truthfully the only way I can keep in touch with my cousins Steven (yes, that's plural -- my family isn't very original when it comes to names), because we are scattered all over the country and not one of them can be bothered to pick up a phone.

I'm sorry, I drifted. I laughed when I got the top theme clue, ''One with a lot of likes,'' because I remembered Moon Unit Zappa's 1982 song with her father, Frank Zappa, ''VALLEY GIRL.'' The stereotypical West Coast VALLEY GIRL was in the habit of saying ''like'' a lot, which is why the clue ''One with a lot of likes'' is such brilliant misdirection:
[Video: Moon Zappa Valley Girl Watch on YouTube.]
One of these theme entries, MAJORITY OWNER, seemed a bit random to me, but the whole set was clever and I decided to give that one a pass.
Now you solve the other theme entries, and you can consider yourself a social media maven.
Tricky Clues

15A: Watch the spelling in the clues: ''Mann of pop'' does not refer to a musician who is a man. There are two N's there, so we're looking for a proper name, and the musician we want is the artist AIMEE Mann.

20A: Most solvers will understand that, because of the spelling, the clue ''Thyme piece?'' is not referring to a watch or clock. It's referring to the herb, but which piece? Today we're giving a nod to the unheralded hero of the English alphabet, the SILENT H.
21A: You need to know your slang terms for money to distinguish between your ''Cheddar'' and your MOOLA.

40A: Hi, Mom and Dad! I know I normally describe things that the kids might not yet know, but you knew that eventually there was going to be a day when I would have to break something down for you. EDM is short for electronic dance music, and it has only been clued that way in The New York Times once before. Before that, it was clued as a graduate teaching degree. If you can imagine. And now it is a whole musical genre that claims techno as a subgenre.
45A: Were you thinking of a stroll, as opposed to a walk in baseball? Today it's the latter, and an AT BAT is not counted as one.
54A: The satirical newspaper, The Onion, made the phrase AREA MAN famous.

9D: Hand up if you filled in SOY here. Me too. Sorry, people, but it's Thursday, and the answer is EEL sauce, that thick and sweet soy-based sauce that is used to baste eel fillets. Its Japanese name is ''Nitsume.'' Over to you, Martin Herbach.

35D: I don't know if you care about these historical side notes, but I find them fascinating. The phrase MADE LOVE debuted in The New York Times Crossword in 1972, and has not been seen since then. Until today. I'm fairly convinced that this oversight is responsible for the state of the world today. Maybe now that it's back, things will get better.
Constructor Notes
I was admonished not to give a real-life villain the satisfaction of being in the puzzle, unless I was prepared to remind him of how appropriately IMMOBILE he is there in his Ecuadorean RECLINER.
AMEN AMEN.
The Tipping Point
Almost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We've got you covered.
Warning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.
Your thoughts?
